requirements.summary: Enable sitewide smooth scrolling via global CSS while strictly honoring prefers-reduced-motion.
acceptanceCriteria: On all pages, normal scrolling animates smoothly without requiring any per-component changes to scroll handlers.
When the OS/browser setting prefers-reduced-motion is enabled, normal scrolling is not smoothed (reverts to default/instant behavior).
No regression to existing animated sections and no new console errors.

file_operations.description: Add a global CSS smooth-scroll rule (e.g., on the root scrolling element) gated under prefers-reduced-motion: no-preference so mousewheel/trackpad scrolling becomes smooth sitewide; ensure the existing prefers-reduced-motion: reduce block continues to force scroll-behavior: auto (non-smooth) without affecting non-scroll animations.

requirements.summary: Refine scroll-to-top easing/duration and standardize section-jump scrolling with consistent reduced-motion behavior.
acceptanceCriteria: Internal route navigations (handled in frontend/src/layouts/RootLayout.tsx) use the updated smoother scroll-to-top behavior.
Homepage section jumps (e.g., ForgeHomePage scrollToSection + HomeSectionIndexFooter buttons) remain smooth when reduced-motion is off and are instant/non-animated when reduced-motion is on.
Scroll-to-top animation cancels cleanly if another scroll-to-top is triggered mid-animation (no jitter).

file_operations.description: Tune the scroll-to-top motion (duration and easing curve) for a smoother feel, and make the implementation more robust by ensuring re-entrant calls cancel cleanly and the returned function is stable (avoid unnecessary effect retriggers). Also introduce a shared helper for section-jump scrolling that mirrors the same prefers-reduced-motion behavior (smooth when allowed, instant otherwise).

Ensure route-change scroll-to-top continues to invoke the updated useSmoothScrollToTop behavior (and remains non-animated for reduced-motion users) without changing routing or scroll restoration logic.

Replace the page-local scrollToSection implementation with the standardized section-jump behavior from the scroll behavior hook/util so section jumps match sitewide smoothness and prefers-reduced-motion handling consistently.
Update the sticky section index footer buttons to use the same standardized section-jump behavior used by the homepage (consistent smooth vs instant behavior based on prefers-reduced-motion).

requirements.summary: Apply light-touch homepage visual polish (spacing, subtle gradients/glows, hierarchy) using existing Tailwind utilities without changing content structure or behavior.
acceptanceCriteria: Hero section: improved spacing and typographic rhythm (headline/subheadline/CTAs) for faster scanability while keeping the same message and CTAs.

Panels/cards (e.g., 'Agents vs. Traditional AI', capabilities, personas, ecosystem): slightly refined borders/glow/gradient treatments to feel cleaner and less harsh while preserving the Ghost Purple/black theme.
Micro-interactions (hover/focus states) feel consistent and slightly more refined on the homepage (no new motion that violates prefers-reduced-motion behavior already defined in CSS).
No changes to routing, data flow, or backend calls.

file_operations.description: Polish homepage presentation with small class-level adjustments only (no new sections/features): tighten hero spacing/rhythm, slightly soften background gradients and glow intensity on panels/cards, and normalize hover/focus treatments across hero CTAs and cards using existing Tailwind + existing Forge utility classes; ensure any motion remains covered by current prefers-reduced-motion CSS behavior.

If needed to support the homepage polish without touching immutable UI component sources, adjust existing Forge utility classes/tokens (e.g., glow softness/gradient subtlety or transition timing tokens) in a minimal, backward-compatible way so the homepage refinements stay consistent with the site theme and reduced-motion rules.
